Aretha Franklin was an American singer, songwriter, and pianist, famously known as the "Queen of Soul." Born on February 25, 1942, in Memphis, Tennessee, she rose to prominence during the 1960s and 1970s, becoming one of the most iconic and influential artists of all time.

Franklin began her music career as a teenager, performing with the New York City's Apollo Theater amateur nights. In 1956, she signed her first record contract with Columbia Records and released her self-titled debut album. Her breakthrough came in 1967 with her first gospel album, "Songs of Faith," which earned her critical acclaim and a devoted fan base.

Throughout the next decade, Aretha Franklin's artistry and talent expanded as she delved into secular music, with her album "I Never Loved a Man the Way I Love You" (1967) becoming a defining work of soul music.
